items.title: Exhausted passengers arrive home after luxury cruise liner runs aground
items.description: About 80 passengers on the Coral Adventurer have been flown home after the cruise ship ran aground on a reef off Papua New Guinea.

items.title: 'Nature is warning us' about climate change, but 'nobody's listening'
items.description: In wet season, Jonathan and his family have to drive, boat and drive again if they want to reach town. The remote NT traditional owner says nature has long been warning us about climate change, "but nobody's listening".

items.title: Destructive winds and heavy rain as Tropical Cyclone Hayley crosses coast
items.description: The storm has been downgraded after bringing severe winds and heavy rain to parts of the north-west Kimberley.

items.title: How illegitimate regulators operate in the name of a tiny African island
items.description: An ABC investigation has identified several individuals involved in a network of illegitimate corporate regulators and service firms.

items.title: 'Teetering on the brink': Fears of Middle East conflict after Saudi strikes in Yemen
items.description: The UAE has denied shipping weapons to Yemeni separatists after Saudi-led forces said they had bombed arms at the port city of Mukalla.

items.title: Would you invest in your favourite craft beer? Nearly 1,000 people have
items.description: Brewer Richard Jeffares's Victorian company raised about $2.5 million from 993 investors in a matter of days through a method called crowd-sourced funding, also known as equity crowdfunding.

items.title: Sportsbet pressured key watchdog into 'watering down' public statement
items.description: Gambling giant Sportsbet pressured the Australian Communications and Media Authority into "watering down" enforcement announcement, the ABC can reveal.

items.title: How to survive a sudden act of mass violence
items.description: The mass shooting in Bondi and other incidents of mass violence around the world have highlighted that violence can strike anywhere. Here are some expert tips on how to escape, hide, and stay safe.

items.title: Denmark becomes first country in world to end letter delivery
items.description: After 401 years, the Danish postal service has ended letter deliveries as the country fully embraces the digital age.

items.title: Man dies in floodwaters in north west Queensland
items.description: Police were called to a vehicle submerged in floodwaters near Normanton where they found the man aged in his 70s.

items.title: Tokyo venture allows housebound people to 'work while teleporting'
items.description: Ory Yoshifuji's Tokyo business employs housebound individuals to operate robots as waitstaff at a cafe and as personal tour guides in the city.

items.title: Robbers use drill to steal $52m of cash and jewellery from German bank
items.description: According to police, the robbers drilled their way into the underground vault room of the savings bank from a parking garage.

items.title: Eurostar cancellations wreak havoc on winter travel, New Year's Eve celebrations
items.description: A disruption on Tuesday prompted the rail company to request train customers postpone their journeys until another time.

items.title: Shock protest against yacht on brink of historic Sydney Hobart victory
items.description: The two-person crewed yacht on the brink of winning the prestigious overall handicap prize in the Sydney to Hobart race is the subject of a protest by a rival, which could potentially deny it victory.

items.title: The day Putin rose from obscurity to one of the world's most powerful jobs
items.description: Vladimir Putin has towered over politics in Russia since ascending to the country's top office, initially as president for eight years, then as prime minister until that pesky thing called the constitution could be altered to allow him to run again.

items.title: Quiz: How much sport do you remember from 2025?
items.description: It was another big year in sport, with Ashes series, world cups, world championships and a long-awaited comeback.

items.title: Where to celebrate New Year's Eve three times in one night
items.description: It's more than 1,000km from any capital city, but Cameron Corner, at the junction of the NSW, Queensland and South Australian borders, reckons it has one of the best New Year's Eve parties going around because it is a triple celebration over three time zones.

items.title: 'Incredibly lucky' bushwalker survives bites from giant brown snake
items.description: A woman hiking on the NSW south coast has survived being bitten twice by an eastern brown snake more than 2 metres long.

items.title: A plane vanished without trace in 2014. Now new tech is looking for MH370
items.description: Malaysia Airlines missing flight MH370, which vanished in 2014, remains one of aviation's enduring mysteries. A new search  is aiming to provide answers.

items.title: How the early Boxing Day Test finish spread far beyond the MCG
items.description: The economic and social impact of the Boxing Day Test reaches far past the pitch and the repercussions of the two-day finish rippled all across Melbourne.

items.title: A year SA searched for answers, but came up short
items.description: As 2025 draws to a close and we look back at the stories that made headlines, for South Australians the year could be summarised as one where we searched for answers, with little results.

items.title: AFP believes Bondi attack gunmen operated alone
items.description: AFP Commissioner Krissy Barrett says there is no evidence the men were instructed to carry out the attack, which left 15 people dead.

items.title: China's message to international 'scoundrels' was directed at the US
items.description: While Donald Trump was distracted, China launched its strongest-ever challenge against Taiwan. Beijing is showing it is ready for war.

items.title: Attacking Putin's home would be 'stupid' move by Ukraine, say experts
items.description: A defence analyst tells the ABC an attack on the Russian President's state residence would be "technically" possible but would not make sense strategically for Ukraine.

items.title: Price of precious metal used in electronics and cars collapses
items.description: The price of palladium — used in electronics — tumbles from recent highs while the prices of other precious metals, including gold and silver, have also sharply declined in recent days.
